etymologies: late 18th century; earliest use found in Encyclopaedia Britannica. From classical Latin pandūra three-stringed lute, and its etymon Hellenistic Greek πανδοῦρα, probably by metathesis from Arabic ṭanbūr and its etymon Persian ṭanbūr

definitions: A Graeco-Roman stringed instrument of the lute type, having a small body, a long thick neck, and usually three strings, which has survived in various forms in the Balkans, Turkey, Egypt, and parts of western Asia. Compare "rebec", "gimbri", "bandurria".
